all right so before we get to all the
exciting talks some really quick updates
so Selium recently announced Celium 117
with some very exciting updates and I'll
quickly go over some important updates
so from a networking and service mesh
perspective Celium now supports
enforcing networking quality of service
at a pod level and you can now use
multicluster service API for global
services in your service in your cluster
mesh and if you wanted to customize your
load balancing algorithms you can now
choose make that choice at a service
level and Amazon's ENI mode now supports
static IPs thanks to Anton who's here
today and even you can even assign
static IPs to
gateways and CM now supports gateway API
1.2.1 with support for HTTP retries and
mirroring fraction of your traffic
and from a security perspective we also
have some really exciting updates right
so we have
improved performance for network policy
enforcement and we you can now
prioritize certain Celium network
policies over others so that those
policies get enforced first and
processed first on the agent before
other policies you also have improved
validation for Celium network policy so
if you ever try to deploy a network
policy only to figure out like why
something's not working you can get some
early feedback soon after you
deploy you also have support for port
ranges in HTTP policies now so you can
define an entire port range to be
redirected to the envy
proxy and you can also now reference
cider groups with labels in network
policies directly so that's a really
handy feature and if you've been
exploring the Celium's host firewall
feature you can now also use two FKDNs
in host
network and we also have some exciting
updates for like regular day two
operations so we have a lot of metrics
now and one metric I'm excited about is
you can actually check which features in
Celium are enabled in each of your nodes
in each of your clusters so you can have
dashboards to figure out wait did I
enable something new in this cluster so
you can actually have metrics for that
you don't have to go through Helm for
that and one of the complaints we've
heard often from users is Hubble
consuming a lot of CPU and there's a lot
of traffic on the node so there's some
interesting improvements to rate limit
the monitor events so this helps in
reducing and making the Hubble CPU
utilization capped at a certain level
and we also have better automated scale
testing in CI uh thanks to great work
from
Marcel and again we also can support now

we're also trying to formalize sig
